Vulnerabilities.Description:
Netsparker Enterprise identified a cookie not marked as HTTPOnly.

HTTPOnly cookies cannot be read by client-side scripts, therefore marking a cookie as HTTPOnly can provide an additional layer of protection against cross-site scripting attacks.
Vulnerabilities.ExternalReferences:
• Netsparker - Security Cookies - HTTPOnly Flag
  • OWASP HTTPOnly Cookies
  • MSDN - ASP.NET HTTPOnly Cookies

HttpRequest.Content:
GET /auth/login.php HTTP/1.1
Host: php.testsparker.com
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://php.testsparker.com/auth/
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/79.0.3945.0 Safari/537.36
X-Scanner: Netsparker Enterprise

HttpResponse.Content:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Set-Cookie: PHPSESSID=e52a07f0fe53c0294ae211bc4481332d; path=/ Server: Apache/2.2.8 (Win32) PHP/5.2.6 Content-Length: 3061 X-Powered-By: PHP/5.2.6 Pragma: no-cache Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT Keep-Alive: timeout=5, max=150 Connection: Keep-Alive Content-Type: text/html Date: Thu, 24 Jun 2021 22:49:36 GMT Cache-Control: no-store, must-revalidate, no-cache, post-check=0, pre-check=0 Netsparker Test Web Site - PHP

Vulnerabilities.Impact: During a cross-site scripting attack, an attacker might easily access cookies and hijack the victim's session.
Vulnerabilities.Name: Cookie Not Marked as HttpOnly
Vulnerabilities.RemedialActions:
1. See the remedy for solution.
  2. Consider marking all of the cookies used by the application as HTTPOnly. (After these changes javascript code will not be able to read cookies.)
Vulnerabilities.RemedialProcedure: Mark the cookie as HTTPOnly. This will be an extra layer of defense against XSS. However this is not a silver bullet and will not protect the system against cross-site scripting attacks. An attacker can use a tool such as XSS Tunnel to bypass HTTPOnly protection.
